company.name: Monarch Services, Inc.
company.business_description: Monarch Services, Inc. operated www.girlslife.com, a website directed to children and young teenagers. Through the website, they displayed online advertising, sold products such as print magazine subscriptions, apparel, books, candy, jewelry, music, and novelties, and promoted products sold by other companies that advertised on their website.

case_info.legal_authority: Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6501-6506, 6502(c), and 6505(d), and Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act (FTC Act), 15 U.S.C. §§ 41-58, 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a)

complaint.factual_background: Defendants Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls' Life, Inc. operated the website www.girlslife.com, directed to children and young teenagers, offering free activities such as bulletin boards, email accounts, electronic postcards, and contests. Since at least April 21, 2000 — the effective date of the COPPA Rule — defendants collected extensive personal information from children under 13, including full names, postal addresses, email addresses, ages, and other sensitive data, without posting an adequate privacy policy, without notifying parents, and without obtaining verifiable parental consent. Defendants also conditioned children's participation in activities on disclosing more personal information than reasonably necessary and provided no mechanism for parents to review or delete their children's data. Defendants disclosed children's personal information to third parties, including Bigmailbox.com and Looksmart Ltd., without parental authorization.

representations_made.description: Defendants collected personal information from children entering contests, including full name, postal address, age, short essays, and parent's daytime telephone number
representations_made.quoted_text: a. Defendants ask children who wish to enter contests to submit their full name, postal address, and, variously, short essays, age, and their parent’s daytime telephone number. (Exhibit A.)

representations_made.description: Defendants asked children to submit full name, email address, and postal addresses to update magazine subscriptions
representations_made.quoted_text: b. Defendants ask children who wish to change the postal address at which they receive defendants’ print magazine Girls’ Life to submit online their full name, email address, old postal address, new postal address, and customer number. COMPLAINT FOR CIVIL PENALTIES, INJUNCTIVE, AND OTHER RELIEF, PAGE 5 OF 12 (Exhibit B.)

representations_made.description: Defendants asked children to submit homepage URLs, which were then publicly disclosed on the website
representations_made.quoted_text: c. Defendants ask children to submit their homepage URLs, which defendants disclose on www.girlslife.com. (Exhibit C.)

representations_made.description: Defendants collected full names and email addresses from children submitting poetry, essays, or stories, and in some instances posted children's full names and ages publicly alongside submissions
representations_made.quoted_text: d. Defendants collect full names and email addresses from children who submit poetry, essays, or stories to the website. (Exhibits D and E.) In some instances, defendants have collected and posted children’s full names and ages on the website together with their written submissions. (See Exhibit E.)

representations_made.description: Defendants, with Bigmailbox.com, required children to submit extensive personal information to open a free email account, then sent marketing emails to those children and disclosed their information to third parties
representations_made.quoted_text: e. Defendants, in conjunction with Bigmailbox.com, Inc., require children who wish to open a free www.girlslife.com email account to submit their full name, an alternate email address, ZIP code, user name, password, a “password reminder” question and answer (in case the user forgets her password), gender, age, occupation (selected from a pull-down menu, e.g., student), and interests. (Email registration page, Exhibit F.) Defendants and Bigmailbox.com, Inc. also ask children opening email accounts to submit their city, state, and country. The email accounts permit children to disclose their personal information to the public. Defendants and Bigmailbox.com, Inc. send direct marketing offers by email to children who register for free email accounts. Defendants and Bigmailbox.com, COMPLAINT FOR CIVIL PENALTIES, INJUNCTIVE, AND OTHER RELIEF, PAGE 6 OF 12 Inc. also disclose children’s personal information to various third parties. (See 9/15/00 www.bigmailbox.com privacy policy, Exhibit G.)

representations_made.description: Defendants, with Looksmart Ltd., required children to submit full name and email address to post on bulletin boards, then disclosed that information publicly online
representations_made.quoted_text: f. Defendants, in conjunction with Looksmart Ltd., ask children who wish to post a message on the Girls’ Life bulletin boards to submit their full name and email address along with the message. (Exhibit H.) Defendants and Looksmart Ltd. disclose all submitted personal information to the public by posting it online. (See Exhibit I.)

representations_made.description: Defendants, with All-Yours Internet Solutions, required children to submit full names and email addresses to send electronic postcards, and that information was retained and used to contact the child later
representations_made.quoted_text: g. Defendants, in conjunction with All-Yours Internet Solutions, ask children who wish to send a Girls’ Life electronic postcard to submit their full name, their email address, the recipient’s full name, the recipient’s email address, and an open-ended message. (Exhibit J.) All-Yours Internet Solutions retains the personal information submitted and uses it later to contact the child to confirm delivery of the electronic postcard. (Id.)

representations_made.description: Defendants did not post any privacy policy prior to approximately October 18, 2000, and the subsequent policy failed to clearly and completely disclose all collection, use, and disclosure practices as required by the Rule
representations_made.quoted_text: 16. Prior to approximately October 18, 2000, defendants did not post any privacy policy. Since then, defendants have posted a privacy policy, but it does not clearly, understandably, or completely disclose all of their information collection, use, and disclosure practices and other disclosures required by the Rule. Defendants’ privacy policy, additionally, is COMPLAINT FOR CIVIL PENALTIES, INJUNCTIVE, AND OTHER RELIEF, PAGE 7 OF 12 posted only on their website’s homepage, and not in close proximity to every place where defendants request personal information. (Exhibit K.)

representations_made.description: Defendants failed to provide direct notice to parents of their practices regarding collection, use, and disclosure of children's personal information
representations_made.quoted_text: 17. Defendant does not provide direct notice to parents of its practices regarding the collection, use, and/or disclosure of children’s personal information and other disclosures required by the Rule.

representations_made.description: Defendants failed to obtain verifiable parental consent before collecting, using, or disclosing children's personal information
representations_made.quoted_text: 18. Defendants fail to obtain verifiable parental consent for collecting, using, or disclosing the personal information of children.

representations_made.description: Defendants provided no means for parents to review or delete information collected from their children
representations_made.quoted_text: 19. Defendants provide no means for parents to review or delete the information collected from their children.

representations_made.description: Defendants did not provide for the security, confidentiality, or integrity of the personal information collected from children
representations_made.quoted_text: 20. Defendants do not provide for the security, confidentiality, or integrity of the personal information collected from children.

counts.title: Failure to Provide Sufficient Website Notice
counts.representation: Defendants collected personal information from children online through numerous activities on www.girlslife.com
counts.fact: Defendants failed to provide sufficient notice on their website of what information they collect from children, how they use it, their disclosure practices, and all other content required by Section 312.4(b) of the Rule
counts.conclusion: Defendants violated Section 312.4(b) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(b), constituting an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act.

counts.title: Failure to Provide Notice to Parents
counts.representation: Defendants collected personal information from children through their website
counts.fact: Defendants failed to provide notice to parents of what information they collect online from children, how they use it, their disclosure practices, and all other required content, in violation of Section 312.4(c) of the Rule
counts.conclusion: Defendants violated Section 312.4(c) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(c), constituting an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act.

counts.title: Failure to Obtain Verifiable Parental Consent
counts.representation: Defendants collected, used, and disclosed personal information from children
counts.fact: Defendants failed to obtain verifiable parental consent before any collection, use, and/or disclosure of personal information from children, in violation of Section 312.5 of the Rule
counts.conclusion: Defendants violated Section 312.5 of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.5, constituting an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act.

counts.title: Failure to Provide Parental Notice and Opt-Out Under Consent Exception
counts.representation: Defendants collected children's personal information in situations that fall under an exception to the Rule's prior parental consent requirement
counts.fact: In those exception situations, defendants failed to provide parents with notice and the opportunity to request that the operator make no further use of the information, in violation of Sections 312.4(c) and 312.5(c) of the Rule
counts.conclusion: Defendants violated Sections 312.4(c) and 312.5(c) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. §§ 312.4(c) and 312.5(c), constituting an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act.

counts.title: Failure to Provide Parental Review and Deletion Rights
counts.representation: Defendants collected and maintained personal information from children
counts.fact: Defendants failed to provide a reasonable means for parents to review the personal information collected from their children and to refuse to permit its further use or maintenance, in violation of Section 312.6 of the Rule
counts.conclusion: Defendants violated Section 312.6 of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.6, constituting an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act.

counts.title: Conditioning Participation on Excess Information Disclosure
counts.representation: Defendants conditioned children's participation in online activities on their submitting personal information
counts.fact: Defendants conditioned children's participation in activities on their disclosing more personal information than is reasonably necessary to participate in those activities, in violation of Section 312.7 of the Rule
counts.conclusion: Defendants violated Section 312.7 of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.7, constituting an unfair or deceptive act or practice in violation of Section 5(a)(1) of the FTC Act.

definitions.Rule: the Federal Trade Commission's Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312, or as the Rule may hereafter be amended.
definitions.child, collects, collection, Commission,: defined as those terms are defined in Section 312.2 of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.2.
definitions.defendants: Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls' Life, Inc. and their officers; and each of the above's successors and assigns, agents, representatives, and employees.

provisions.title: Injunction Against COPPA Rule Violations
provisions.summary: Defendants and all persons acting in concert with them are permanently enjoined from violating any provision of the COPPA Rule, as currently promulgated or as amended in the future.

requirements.description: Defendants, successors, assigns, officers, agents, servants, employees, attorneys, and all persons in active concert with them are enjoined from violating, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, website, or other device, any provision of the Rule as promulgated and as it may be modified in the future.
requirements.quoted_text: 6. Defendants, their successors and assigns, and their officers, agents, servants, employees and attorneys, and all persons in active concert or participation with any one or more of them who receive actual notice of this Consent Decree by personal service or otherwise, are hereby enjoined from violating, directly or through any corporation, subsidiary, division, website, or other device, any provision of the Rule as promulgated and as it may be modified in the future. A copy of the Rule is attached hereto as “Appendix A” and incorporated herein as if fully set forth verbatim.

provisions.title: Consumer Education Remedy — FTC KidzPrivacy Notice
provisions.summary: For five years from entry of the Consent Decree, defendants must place a clear and conspicuous FTC KidzPrivacy notice (with hyperlink) in their privacy policy, direct notices to parents, and at each location on their website(s) where personal information is collected.

requirements.description: For a period of five (5) years from the date of entry, defendants must place a clear and conspicuous FTC KidzPrivacy notice in bold typeface within the privacy policy required by Section 312.4(b) of the Rule, within direct notices to parents required by Section 312.4(c), and at each location on their website(s) where personal information is collected; where posted online or delivered electronically, the notice must be in the form of a hyperlink to www.ftc.gov/kidzprivacy.
requirements.quoted_text: 7. For a period of five (5) years from the date of entry of this Consent Decree, defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall, in connection with the operation of any website or online service directed in whole or in part to children, place a clear and conspicuous notice (1) within the privacy policy required to be posted on its website(s) by Section 312.4(b) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(b); (2) within the direct notice required to be sent to parents by Section 312.4(c) of the Rule, 16 C.F.R. § 312.4(c); and (3) at each location on its website(s) where personal information is collected, which states as follows in bold typeface: NOTICE: Visit www.ftc.gov/kidzprivacy for information from the Federal Trade Commission about protecting children’s privacy online. Where the above notice is posted on a website or delivered via email or other electronic service, it shall be in the form of a hyperlink to www.ftc.gov/kidzprivacy. The Federal Trade Commission may change the hyperlink/URL upon thirty (30) days prior written notice to defendants, or their successors or CONSENT DECREE AND ORDER FOR CIVIL PENALTIES, INJUNCTIVE, AND OTHER RELIEF, PAGE 3 OF 13 assigns.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — $30,000 Payment
provisions.summary: Defendants Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls' Life, Inc. must jointly and severally pay a civil penalty of $30,000 to the United States.

requirements.description: Defendants Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls' Life, Inc., and their successors and assigns, shall pay a civil penalty of $30,000 pursuant to Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the FTC Act; defendants are jointly and severally responsible for paying the penalty.
requirements.quoted_text: 8. Defendants Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls’ Life, Inc., and their successors and assigns, shall pay to plaintiff a civil penalty, pursuant to Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(m)(1)(A), in the amount of thirty thousand dollars ($30,000). Defendants are jointly and severally responsible for paying the penalty.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty — Payment Mechanics
provisions.summary: Defendants must pay the $30,000 civil penalty on the date of entry of the Consent Decree by certified or cashier's check payable to the Treasurer of the United States and delivered to the Office of Consumer Litigation.

requirements.description: Defendants shall make the civil penalty payment on the date of entry of this Consent Decree by certified or cashier's check made payable to the Treasurer of the United States and delivered to the Office of Consumer Litigation, Civil Division, U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, D.C. 20530.
requirements.quoted_text: 9. Defendants Monarch Services, Inc. and Girls’ Life, Inc., and their successors and assigns, shall make the payment required by Paragraph 8 on the date of entry of this Consent Decree by certified or cashier’s check made payable to the Treasurer of the United States and delivered to: the Office of Consumer Litigation, Civil Division, U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, D.C. 20530, for appropriate disposition.

provisions.title: Default in Civil Penalty Payment
provisions.summary: If defendants default on payment for more than ten days beyond the due date, the entire unpaid penalty plus interest becomes immediately due and payable.

requirements.description: In the event of any default in payment continuing for ten (10) days beyond the due date, the entire unpaid penalty together with interest computed pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1961 from the date of default shall immediately become due and payable.
requirements.quoted_text: 10. In the event of any default in payment, which default continues for ten (10) days beyond the due date of payment, the entire unpaid penalty, together with interest, as computed pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1961, from the date of default to the date of payment, shall immediately become due and payable.

provisions.title: Deletion of Children's Personal Information
provisions.summary: Defendants must delete all personal information collected from children through www.girlslife.com between April 21, 2000 and the date of entry of this Consent Decree.

requirements.description: Defendants and their successors and assigns shall delete all personal information collected from children through www.girlslife.com at any time from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry of this Consent Decree.
requirements.quoted_text: 11. Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall delete all personal information collected from children through www.girlslife.com at any time from April 21, 2000 through the date of entry of this Consent Decree.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment — Current Personnel
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide copies of the Consent Decree and COPPA compliance guide to all current principals, officers, directors, managers, and relevant employees, obtain signed acknowledgments from each, and submit a compliance statement to the FTC within ten days.

requirements.description: Defendants and their successors and assigns shall provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the FTC compliance guide to each current principal, officer, director, manager, and all current employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys with responsibilities related to the subject matter of this Consent Decree; secure from each such person a signed statement acknowledging receipt; and within ten (10) days of complying, submit to the Commission a signed statement setting forth the fact and manner of compliance, including the name and title of each person to whom copies were provided.
requirements.quoted_text: 12. Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the Federal Trade Commission compliance guide entitled How to Comply with the Children’s Online Privacy Protection Rule (Nov. 1999) (“compliance guide”) (attached hereto as “Appendix B”) to each of their current principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all current employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys having responsibilities related to the subject matter of this Consent Decree, secure from each such person a signed statement acknowledging receipt of a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide, and shall, within ten (10) days of complying with this paragraph, submit to the Commission a signed statement setting forth the fact and manner of defendants’ compliance, including the name and title of each person to whom a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide has been provided.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment — Future Personnel
provisions.summary: Defendants must provide the Consent Decree and compliance guide to all future relevant personnel within thirty days of their assuming such responsibilities, obtain signed acknowledgments, and maintain those records available for FTC inspection upon request.

requirements.description: Defendants and their successors and assigns shall provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide to each future principal, officer, director, manager, and all future employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys with related responsibilities within thirty (30) days after the person assumes such position or responsibilities; secure from each a signed and dated acknowledgment; and maintain copies of those signed statements and related compliance information, making them available to the FTC upon request.
requirements.quoted_text: 13. Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall provide a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide to each of their future principals, officers, directors, and managers, and to all future employees, agents, representatives, and attorneys having responsibilities related to the subject matter of this Consent Decree, and secure from each such person a signed and dated statement acknowledging receipt of a copy of this Consent Decree and the compliance guide, within thirty (30) days after the person assumes such position or responsibilities. Defendants shall maintain copies of the signed statements, as well as other information regarding the fact and manner of their compliance, including the name and title of each person to whom a copy of the Consent Decree and compliance guide has been provided and, upon request, shall make the statements and other information available CONSENT DECREE AND ORDER FOR CIVIL PENALTIES, INJUNCTIVE, AND OTHER RELIEF, PAGE 5 OF 13 to the Federal Trade Commission.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Within sixty days of entry and at such other times as the FTC requires, defendants must file a sworn written compliance report detailing their adherence to the Consent Decree, including copies of privacy notices, parental consent methods, and data security procedures.

requirements.description: Within sixty (60) days after entry of this Consent Decree, and at such other times as the FTC may require, defendants and their successors and assigns shall file with the Commission a written report sworn under penalty of perjury setting forth in detail the manner and form of compliance, including: (a) copies of each different privacy notice for www.girlslife.com and other covered websites; (b) statement of each location of privacy notices and copies of information-collection pages; (c) copies of each different privacy notice to parents; (d) statement of when and how parental notices are provided; (e) statement of verifiable parental consent methods; (f) statement of means provided for parents to review and refuse further use of children's information; (g) statement of why each type of information collected is reasonably necessary; and (h) statement of procedures to protect confidentiality, security, and integrity of children's personal information.
requirements.quoted_text: 14. Within sixty (60) days after entry of this Consent Decree, and at such other times as the Federal Trade Commission may require, defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall file with the Commission a written report, sworn to under penalty of perjury, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which they have complied and are complying with this Consent Decree. This report shall include but not be limited to: a. a copy of each different privacy notice for www.girlslife.com and for any other of defendants’ websites or online services subject to the Rule; b. a statement setting forth in detail each place where the privacy notice is located on www.girlslife.com and on any other of defendants’ websites or online services subject to the Rule, and a copy of each screen or page on which the website collects personal information; c. a copy of each different privacy notice to parents; d. a statement setting forth in detail when and how notices to parents are provided; e. a statement setting forth in detail the methods used to obtain verifiable parental consent prior to any collection, use, and/or disclosure of personal information from children; f. a statement setting forth in detail the means provided for parents to review the CONSENT DECREE AND ORDER FOR CIVIL PENALTIES, INJUNCTIVE, AND OTHER RELIEF, PAGE 6 OF 13 personal information collected from their children and to refuse to permit its further use or maintenance; g. a statement setting forth in detail why each type of information collected is reasonably necessary for the provision of the particular related activity; and h. a statement setting forth in detail the procedures used to protect the confidentiality, security, and integrity of personal information collected from children.

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: For five years from entry, defendants must maintain and make available to the FTC within seven days of written request all documents demonstrating compliance, including copies of information collection forms, web pages, and representations about data practices.

requirements.description: For a period of five years from the date of entry, defendants and their successors and assigns shall maintain and make available to the FTC for inspection and copying within seven (7) days of receipt of a written request a print or electronic copy in HTML format of all documents demonstrating compliance, including a sample copy of every information collection form, web page, or screen, and a sample copy of each document containing any representation regarding defendants' collection, use, and disclosure practices pertaining to personal information; each web page copy shall be accompanied by the URL; defendants are not required to retain a document for longer than three years after creation or to retain copies of amended web pages where the amendment does not affect compliance obligations.
requirements.quoted_text: 15. For a period of five years from the date of entry of this Consent Decree, defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall maintain and make available to the Federal Trade Commission for inspection and copying within seven (7) days of the date of receipt of a written request, a print or electronic copy in HTML format of all documents demonstrating compliance with the terms and provisions of this Consent Decree, including, but not limited to, a sample copy of every information collection form, web page, or screen, and a sample copy of each document containing any representation regarding defendants’ collection, use, and disclosure practices pertaining to personal information. Each web page copy shall be accompanied by the URL of the Web page where the material was posted online. Electronic copies shall include all text and graphics files, audio scripts, and other computer files used in presenting information on the Internet. Provided, however, that defendants shall not be required by this paragraph to retain a document for longer than three years after the document is created; or retain a print or electronic copy of any amended web page or screen to the CONSENT DECREE AND ORDER FOR CIVIL PENALTIES, INJUNCTIVE, AND OTHER RELIEF, PAGE 7 OF 13 extent that the amendment does not affect defendants’ compliance obligations under this Consent Decree.
requirements.deadline: 5 years (records available within 7 days of request)

provisions.title: Notification of Business Changes
provisions.summary: Defendants must notify the FTC at least thirty days prior to any business change that may affect compliance obligations under the Consent Decree, including mergers, dissolutions, bankruptcy filings, or name/address changes.

requirements.description: Defendants and their successors and assigns shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in the business of defendants that may affect compliance obligations, including any merger, incorporation, dissolution, assignment, sale, creation or dissolution of a subsidiary or affiliate, proposed bankruptcy petition, or change in corporate name or address; where defendants learn of such a change less than thirty (30) days before it occurs, they shall notify the Commission as soon as practicable.
requirements.quoted_text: 16. Defendants, and their successors and assigns, shall notify the Commission at least thirty (30) days prior to any change in the business of defendants that may affect compliance obligations arising under this Consent Decree, including, but not limited to, any merger, incorporation, dissolution, assignment, sale or other action that would result in the emergence of a successor corporation; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate; the proposed filing of a bankruptcy petition; or a change in the corporate name or address. Provided, however, that, with respect to any proposed change in the corporations about which defendants, their successors and assigns, learn less than thirty (30) days prior to the date such action is to take place, they shall notify the Commission as soon as is practicable after obtaining such knowledge. 17. Defendants are hereby required, in accordance

provisions.title: Taxpayer Identification Numbers
provisions.summary: Defendants must furnish their taxpayer identifying numbers (SSN or EIN) to the FTC pursuant to 31 U.S.C. § 7701 for purposes of collecting and reporting on any delinquent amounts.

requirements.description: Defendants are required, in accordance with 31 U.S.C. § 7701, to furnish to the FTC each of their taxpayer identifying numbers (social security number or employer identification number), which shall be used for purposes of collecting and reporting on any delinquent amount arising out of their relationship with the government.
requirements.quoted_text: practicable after obtaining such knowledge. 17. Defendants are hereby required, in accordance with 31 U.S.C. § 7701, to furnish to the Federal Trade Commission each of their taxpayer identifying numbers (social security number or employer identification number), which shall be used for purposes of collecting and reporting on any delinquent amount arising out of their relationship with the government.

provisions.title: Submission Address for Reports and Notices
provisions.summary: All reports, submissions, and notices required by Paragraphs 11–17 must be sent by certified mail to the FTC's Associate Director, Division of Advertising Practices.

requirements.description: All reports, submissions, and notices required by Paragraphs 11–17 of this Consent Decree shall be sent by certified mail to the Associate Director, Division of Advertising Practices, Bureau of Consumer Protection, Federal Trade Commission, 600 Pennsylvania Avenue NW, Washington, DC 20580, Attention: United States v. Monarch Services, Inc., et al.
requirements.quoted_text: 18. All reports, submissions, and notices required by Paragraphs 11 - 17 of this Consent Decree shall be sent by certified mail to: Associate Director, Division of Advertising Practices Bureau of Consumer Protection Federal Trade Commission 600 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW CONSENT DECREE AND ORDER FOR CIVIL PENALTIES, INJUNCTIVE, AND OTHER RELIEF, PAGE 8 OF 13 Washington, DC 20580 Attention: United States v. Monarch Services, Inc., et al.

provisions.title: Continuing Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter to enable any party to apply for further orders necessary for interpretation, modification, enforcement, or punishment of violations of the Consent Decree.

requirements.description: The Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of enabling any of the parties to apply to the Court at any time for such further orders or directives as may be necessary or appropriate for the interpretation or modification of this Consent Decree, for the enforcement of compliance therewith, or for the punishment of violations thereof.
requirements.quoted_text: 19. This Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for the purposes of enabling any of the parties to this Consent Decree to apply to the Court at any time for such further orders or directives as may be necessary or appropriate for the interpretation or modification of this Consent Decree, for the enforcement of compliance therewith, or for the punishment of violations thereof.

duration.termination_text: For a period of five (5) years from the date of entry of this Consent Decree
